entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued February 14 at 3:06AM EST until February 14 at 5:00AM EST by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Ocean and Coastal Ocean.
* WHEN...Until 5 AM EST early this morning.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Lingering minor tidal flooding remains along the backbays of Ocean County as water continues to recede. After water finishes receding, no additional coastal flooding is expected through the end of the week.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued February 14 at 3:06AM EST until February 14 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...In New Jersey, Northwestern Burlington. In Pennsylvania, Lower Bucks.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM EST this morning.
* IMPACTS...At this level, flooding begins on the most vulnerable roads along tidal waterways. Some partial or full road closures are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Minor coastal flooding will occur around the times of the high tides through this morning. Increased fresh water runoff today may lead to elevated water levels, especially along tidal river tributaries. After the early morning high tide today, no additional coastal flooding is expected through the end of the week.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 14 at 12:55AM MST until February 16 at 5:00PM MST by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total storm snowfall accumulations of 8 to 15 inches for the Snowy Range at elevations above 9000 feet. Total storm snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 inches for the Sierra Madre Range at elevations above 9000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Sierra Madre Range and Snowy Range.
* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 5 PM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Whiteout conditions are possible on Thursday afternoon and evening when wind gusts are strongest.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This snowfall will accumulate over a prolonged period of time, with periods of no snowfall occurring followed by short periods of moderate to heavy snowfall at times. This could disorient individuals who plan on being outdoors for prolonged periods of time due to low visibility. Snowfall should begin to dissipate by Friday evening, but light snowfall accumulations will still be possible through early Saturday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 5 PM MST FRIDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 14 at 2:45AM EST by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
HAZARDS...A snow squall which can rapidly reduce visibility to a half of a mile.
LOCATION AND MOVEMENT...At 243 AM EST, a snow squall was along a line extending from 16 miles northwest of Bellefonte to 13 miles south of Lock Haven and moving south at 15 MPH.
THIS SQUALL WILL BE NEAR... Madisonburg, Aaronsburg, and Millheim around 250 AM EST. Bellefonte and Coburn around 255 AM EST. Spring Mills around 300 AM EST. Poe Valley State Park around 305 AM EST. Pleasant Gap around 310 AM EST.
For those driving on Interstate 80, this includes areas between the Woodland and Lamar exits, specifically from mile markers 124 to 172.
This includes Interstate 99 from mile markers 80 to 85.
SAFETY INFO... Use extra caution if you must travel into or through this squall. Rapid changes in visibility and potentially slick roads may lead to accidents.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clearfield; Northern Centre; Southern Centre; Southern Clinton; Union; Snyder

cap:parameter.value: A SNOW SQUALL WILL AFFECT PARTS OF SOUTHERN CLINTON...NORTHERN CENTRE...UNION...CLEARFIELD...SNYDER...AND SOUTHERN CENTRE COUNTIES

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 10:38PM PST by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary: Freezing fog will impact travel across the Spokane area. Cameras and observers were showing visibilities below 1/4 of a mile around town. Additionally, the fog could be creating slick roadways with temperatures well below freezing. Motorists should be prepared for slower travel times, use low beams, and drive with caution.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 13 at 8:49PM AKST until February 15 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 10 to 16 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph. Visibility reduced to one-mile or less at times.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on difficult travel conditions. Heavy snow and localized areas of blowing snow could cause significantly reduced visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will continue for the next few days across the Bristol Bay zone. Snow intensity will increase this evening across portions of Southern Bristol Bay, including Pilot Point and Port Heiden. The heaviest snow will fall tonight into Wednesday afternoon. Meanwhile, snow intensity will increase Wednesday evening for areas west of Dillingham, including Togiak, Goodnews Bay, and Platinum. The heaviest snow there will fall from Wednesday evening through Thursday morning before becoming lighter during the afternoon hours. Precipitation intensity should keep most precipitation in the form of snow. However, rain could mix in at times for areas west of Dillingham Thursday night into Friday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 13 at 8:49PM AKST until February 15 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 10 inches. Northerly winds gusting as high as 45 mph. Visibility reduced to a half-mile or less at times.
* WHERE...Alaska Peninsula.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM AKST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on difficult travel conditions. Heavy snow and areas of blowing snow could cause significantly reduced visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will begin Wednesday morning across the Alaska Peninsula. The heaviest snow will fall Wednesday afternoon through Wednesday evening. The heaviest snow will also coincide with elevated northerly winds which could cause significant reductions in visibility; this is especially true for areas east of Cold Bay, including Nelson Lagoon. Snow will become lighter Thursday evening and linger into early Friday morning before ending.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 13 at 10:14PM CST until February 15 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Louisville has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Kentucky...
Green River at Rochester affecting Ohio, Muhlenberg and Butler Counties.
Green River near Mammoth Cave affecting Edmonson County.
.Heavy rain from the past few days will cause the river to rise.
For the GREEN RIVER...including Mammoth Cave, Munfordville, Brownsville, Woodbury, Rochester...elevated river levels are forecast.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Green River near Mammoth Cave.
* WHEN...From this evening to Thursday evening.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 13 at 6:27PM AKST until February 14 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:

* WHERE...Kivalina and Red Dog Dock, Baldwin Peninsula, and Kotzebue.
* WHEN...Until 3 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Large snow drifts will form.

Locations at lower elevations will have warmer temperatures and longer periods of rain and freezing rain before a transition back to mainly snow late tonight.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 13 at 9:44PM EST until February 15 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following county, Colleton.
* WHEN...Until 400 AM EST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 941 PM EST, Colleton County Emergency Management continued to report minor flooding in the Ireland Creek area. - At 9:15 pm Tuesday, a USGS stream gage located on the North Jefferies Boulevard bridge across Ireland Creek continued to report water levels above the minor flood stage of 8.23 feet. Minor flooding, which occurs at 8.0 feet continues along Ireland Creek, with water still covering entire sections of Ivanhoe Road, Ireland Creek Drive, and the intersection of Ireland Creek Drive and Dowling Avenue. Water levels appear to have peaked, but will be very slow to recede through the night. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Walterboro.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 13 at 8:59PM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Wayne, Tattnall, Toombs and Appling Counties.
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Toombs, Montgomery and Jeff Davis Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Wednesday evening at 900 PM EST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Bankfull conditions occur along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Some flooding begins in low lying areas around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage in south Montgomery County. The water will approach portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 13.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding occurs in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water reaches the top of the public boat ramp by the bridge. Flood waters expand in low lying areas in south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will begin to cover portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 11.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tonight and continue rising to 15.6 feet Sunday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jeff Davis, GA; Montgomery, GA; Toombs, GA

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 13 at 7:46PM CST until February 16 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Memphis TN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...This is a potential dam breach watch declaration by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Vicksburg District for Arkabutla Dam located in DeSoto and Tate Counties in Northwest Mississippi. The physical condition of the dam is unchanged, and a dam breach is not imminent. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Vicksburg District has increased the potential breach emergency status at Arkabutla Dam from ALERT to WATCH because of increasing reservoir levels due to recent rainfall.
* WHERE...A portion of North Mississippi, including the following counties, Coahoma, DeSoto, Panola, Quitman, Tallahatchie, Tate and Tunica.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...Dam failure may result in flash flooding of low-lying areas below the dam.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of central Alabama, including the following county, Cherokee.
* WHEN...Until 915 AM CST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 740 PM CST, Reporting gauges indicate elevated levels along the Chattooga River above Weiss Lake. Cedar Bluff, Gaylesville, Cornwall Furnace Park, Eastern Weiss Lake and Western Weiss Lake.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 3:19PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Strong southerly chinook winds blowing across the Alaska Range will continue into Wednesday and possibly into Thursday. Temperatures this morning have risen into the 30s this morning along many highways across Interior Alaska, with some lower 40s occuring south of Fairbanks. These warm temperatures will cause walking and driving surfaces to become slippery. Some valley locations north and east of Fairbanks will remain below freezing.
Temperatures will remain very warm along the Alaska Range through Thursday and partial melting of snow and ice may occur, making travel surfaces more slippery.
Areas further north such as near Fairbanks will likely have hill top temperatures remain near freezing the next several days, while valleys will have temperatures fluctuate from near freezing during the day and back into the teens or single digits at night. This will cause travel surfaces in hills to become more slippery over the next several days as snow and ice starts to melt. Valley locations could get more slippery as well.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued February 13 at 5:28PM EST until February 14 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways (4.0 to 14.3 feet Mean Lower Low Water).
* WHERE...Eastern Massachusetts coastal areas, including Cape Cod and the Islands.
* WHEN...From 1 AM to 4 AM EST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the lowest lying areas along the east coast, including Morrissey Boulevard in Boston and coastal roads on the North Shore from Salem and Gloucester to Newburyport. Rough surf may cause some splashover onto coastal roads. On Nantucket, many roads near Nantucket Harbor become impassable with 1 to 2 feet of water and affects access to the ferry terminals. This includes Easy Street, South Beach Street, Easton Street, Walsh Street, Willard Street, and Straight Wharf. On the Cape, shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affect low lying areas in Provincetown, mainly near the airport and Race Point Road. In Truro, flooding up to one foot deep affects low lying areas near Pamet Harbor and along the Pamet River. On Martha's Vineyard, low lying areas and roads near Edgartown Harbor, including the Chappy Ferry Dock will experience minor flooding. Shallow flooding may also approach Five Corners in Vineyard Haven.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Essex; Suffolk; Eastern Norfolk; Eastern Plymouth; Barnstable; Dukes; Nantucket

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 2:00PM PST by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
A Pacific storm system is expected to move into the forecast area beginning midday Wednesday, spreading rain/snow mix and snow across northern and central Nevada. Light valley rain and mountain snow will be present across most of northern Nevada with snow levels around 5500-6000 feet. Snowfall amounts of 1-3 inches are expected across Northern Elko County and 3-6 inches in the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range Wednesday evening through Thursday morning. The valley floors for the rest of northern and central Nevada will see accumulations of less than an inch. West- southwest winds of 15-20 mph with gusts approaching 35-40 mph will be situated over the ridge lines and higher terrain, leading to blowing and drifting snow. Drier conditions are expected for the rest of the day Thursday as the storm system exits the region.
Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Elko County; Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County; Southwest Elko County; South Central Elko County

cap:parameter.value: High Elevation Snow across Northern Nevada Wednesday through Thursday

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 13 at 1:28PM MST until February 14 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 3 feet in the Tetons and 12 to 24 inches possible in the Gros Ventres. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 5 AM MST Wednesday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Wednesday afternoon through Friday morning.

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 13 at 5:11AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AVWTFX
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE GALLATIN NATIONAL FOREST AVALANCHE CENTER.
ISSUED ON February 13 2024 AT 05:03 am
AVALANCHE WARNING
The Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center is issuing a Backcountry Avalanche Warning for the Bridger Range near Bozeman. New and wind-drifted snow overloaded an exceptionally weak snowpack, creating very dangerous avalanche conditions. Natural and human-triggered avalanches are likely. Avoid avalanche terrain and avalanche runout zones. The avalanche danger is HIGH on all slopes. Contact the Gallatin National Forest Avalanche Center for more detailed information.
Website: www.mtavalanche.com
Avalanche Hotline: 406-587-6981
This warning will expire or be updated by 6:00 a.m. on Wednesday, February 14th.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Big Belt, Bridger and Castle Mountains

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 2:14PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong low pressure system will bring a large amount of warm and moist air over Western Alaska starting Monday into Wednesday. Areas can expect a mix of snow and freezing rain with this system as it moves north. Freezing rain chances will reach as far north as Kivalina by Tuesday afternoon. Ice accumulations of up to one tenth of an inch are possible, with snow amounts ranging from 2 to 5 inches where Winter Storm Warnings are not in effect. Higher snow totals are likely in the Bendeleben Mountains and where warnings are in effect.
The system will also bring strong southeast winds gusting as high as 50 mph to the West Coast and to hills near the coast from Monday afternoon through Tuesday night. This will cause sea levels to rise 1 to 2 feet south of the Bering Strait on Tuesday and Wednesday. While flooding of infrastructure is not expected, these strong winds may cause water to be pushed on top of the sea ice making travel difficult.
Residents should stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg and prepare for a stormy start to the week.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Seward Peninsula; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Strong Winds And Mixed Precipitation Early This Week

entry.summary:
AVWGJT
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE FOREST SERVICE UTAH AVALANCHE CENTER.
THE FOREST SERVICE UTAH AVALANCHE CENTER IN MOAB HAS ISSUED A BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH.
* TIMINGIN EFFECT FROM 6 AM MST THIS MORNING TO 6 AM MST SATURDAY
* AFFECTED AREAFOR THE LA SAL AND ABAJO MOUNTAINS OF SOUTHEASTERN UTAH
* AVALANCHE DANGERDANGEROUS AVALANCHE CONDITIONS ARE DEVELOPING
* IMPACTSA STRONG STORM SYSTEM ON FRIDAY IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE THE AVALANCHE DANGER WITH DANGEROUS CONDITIONS EXPECTED THROUGH THE WEEKEND. NATURAL AND HUMAN TRIGGERED AVALANCHES ARE LIKELY. TRAVEL IN AVALANCHE TERRAIN IS NOT RECOMMENDED. STAY OFF OF AND OUT FROM UNDER SLOPES STEEPER THAN 30 DEGREES.
BACKCOUNTRY TRAVELERS SHOULD CONSULT WWW.UTAHAVALANCHECENTER.ORG OR CALL 1-888-999-4019 FOR MORE DETAILED INFORMATION.
